newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Kl overnight falls to 6.0/3 pct on new funds.
newsitem.headline: Kl overnight falls to 6.0/3 pct on new funds.

text.p: The overnight interbank rate fell to 6.00/30 percent from 8.00/50 just ahead of the market's close due to "unexpected" funds with a few large local banks, dealers said on Wednesday.
They said the overnight rate fell from 8.0 percent in just 15 minutes after the local banks came in to lend around 0800 GMT.
"Some large local banks seem to have got some unexpected funds very late, by which time most people had already covered their positions," said a dealer with a large local bank.
"So when they started lending, the rate dropped," he added.
Some dealers said it was possible that the central bank, Bank Negara, returned some of the funds borrowed directly from select banks as part of its open market operations.
No confirmation was available from Bank Negara, which does not comment on its money market operations.
"It seems like a temporary mismatch. And the amount does not seem very large, it was just the timing," one dealer said.
He said the market would remain tight for the next one month until the festival season ends in the middle of February.
The dealers said banks were hoarding cash in their vaults to allow depositors to withdraw for the twin celebrations of Eid al-Fitr and Chinese Lunar New Year festivals in mid-February.
One-week money was at 7.50/60 percent, two-week was at 7.40/50 and three-week at 7.35/40, all unchanged from Tuesday.
One-month to one-year tenors were all quoted at 7.35 to 7.40 percent, the dealers said.
